loans.name: Maricris

texts.en:
Maricris operates a general store. She wants to borrow a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional capital. She manages the business patiently and has in her mind that “patience is the key to success”. She is 28 years old, married to Alazen, a farm laborer in their village. They are blessed with two children: Christian Earl Cedrick is 5 years old and Aliyah is 1 year old. The family resides in the village of Pallua Norte Tuguegarao City. 

According to Maricris, she will use the loan in sustaining her general store. Selling has been her passion since her childhood and she really enjoys the business. She believes that aside from money, a business will become more successful if it is managed with passion. Some of the loan's use will be in purchasing five kilos of sugar, ten kilos of rice, milk, coffee, toothpaste, fragrance soap, and mild detergent soap. Maricris hopes that someday her business will become productive through the support of Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase items for her general store

loans.name: Rafiki Group

texts.en:
Wafeba is a member of the Rafiki borrower group in Msamvu,Morogoro,she is 24 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child.her child is aged 1 year.

Wafeba started her own  clothing business selling clothes5 years ago,she works 12 hours aday and earn monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Wafeba`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 300,000 Tanzania shillings in order to buy more clothes for sale.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Wafeba hopes to save money and expand her business.

Amina is another member of the same borrower group,she also requested the loan amount 200,000Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Oco

texts.en:
Oco N. is from the village of El Salvador, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old. Oco is married and has four school-age children. To make a living, Oco owns and operates a business butchering and selling pork and chicken  meat in the market. Oco has been in business for over six years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Oco joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Oco is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Oco from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Tsetsegsaikhan

texts.en:
Tsetsegsaikhan is 44 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Chingeltei district in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Her husband is a civil engineer and her eldest daughter goes to kindergarten, while the other two children are at home. Tsetsegsaikhan started to trade in the “Khuchit shonkhor” food market with her mother in 2002. Her mother runs a meat business. Since she started her business, Tsetsegsaikhan has been able to gain experience while expanding her business with the profits. She purchases vegetables for 1,000,000 tugrugs every three days and sells them. Her monthly profits exceed 200,000-350,000 tugrugs. 

In the future, she hopes to expand her market stall into a specialized vegetable store and operate on a wholesale trade. She thinks that there is less risk in this type of business, as vegetables are in demand daily. The family lives in their own ger (yurt/tent) and the busiest season for them is the summer time. They are preparing to build a house this fall. Tsetsegsaikhan is a hardworking businesswoman, with good business ideas. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (approx. $1,382 USD) loan to purchase more vegetables that will enable her to increase her business' profitability. In the picture: Tsetsegsaikhan and her family.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
“Patience is the key to success” says Julius. He is persevering to work hard and striving to uplift their family from poverty by operating his passenger tricycle.  He is from the village of Almaguer South, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. He is a graduate of vocational course and married Cherryl. They were blessed with three children. The eldest is now in the elementary level. His greatest ambition in life is to give all his children the best education.  

He is requesting to avail a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP13, 000 for the maintenance of his motorcycle. According to him, he must maintain the motor very well for his family lives lies on it. He is also concerns on his daily passengers safety thus, wanted the motor vehicle to be overhauled. He is just earning an average net income of PHP200 daily from his daily transport activity and it is of big help to provide his family daily needs. He hopes that someday, aside from maintaining his transport business, his wife could somehow have the chance to venture in vending or selling business. That way, they will help each other towards the progress of their family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia is the mother of two and married to Ben C., who is 38 years old and working as a farmer. Their two children are Oliver Jr., 14 years old, and Bertsel, 12 years old. They are currently residing in the rural village of San Lorenzo Ilagan, Isabela. 

Olivia is a rice seller in their village and also a hog farmer. According to Olivia, her small businesses are very helpful because when there is an urgent financial need, she can just sell any of her full grown hogs to comply with their needs. 

She wants to improve her rice selling business and she is hoping to obtain a loan of PHP 6,000.00.  She knows that rice is very in demand since it is included in every meal of Filipinos.

loans.use: To improve her rice selling business

loans.name: Handmaa

texts.en: Khandmaa is a 57-year-old, single mother of two living in a "ger" (nomadic housing tent) district on the plot of land she owns in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. Her daughter attends a university while her son works and lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Since 1993, Khandmaa has been selling clothing through her stall at the local market in Arvaikheer. She purchases clothes in Erlian, China, once a month. With the success of her business, Khandmaa pays tuition for her daugther and plans to expand her business. Khandmaa is requesting 800,000 tugrugs (approx. $552 USD) to purchase more clothes.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios is 44 years old. She lives in the village of San Jose in Santiago City. She is married to Ronaldo C., who is a rice famer. She manufactures barbecue sticks in their village. She earns income from merely making sticks, dried under the heat of the sun and will sell to buyers in volumes. Each bundle of sticks cost only PHP3 and for her to generate big income she must be patient and work very hard. 

She wants to borrow loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional capital in her stick making business. She will use the amount to buy hardened bamboo, which is the common material used in the business. The more bamboo she can buy, the more sticks she can produce. She hopes that Kiva lenders will allow her to obtain a loan because her business is a big help in providing her family’s daily necessities.

loans.use: To purchase bamboo

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel L. manages a community-based store in her village at General Balao of Solana, Cagayan. She is an energetic woman, untiringly maintaining her business, keeping household chores and taking care of her children. She started her store in 1995. She purchases her products in the big grocery store in the town proper of Solana. 

She wishes to obtain a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP 6,000 as additional capital in order to improve her store and keep up with her business' competitors. Maribel is also happy that her husband, Domingo, is helping her to manage the business. Their five children are their inspiration, to work harder to give the children a bright future.

loans.use: To improve her store and keep up with competitors

loans.name: Letty

texts.en:
Letty A. is from the village of Mangidkid. She is 48 years old, and is married with three adult children. To make a living, Letty raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Letty has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 1999, Letty joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Letty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Letty is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her fourteenth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: For porgress business

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en: Concepcion is a very caring mother to her four children.  She is married to Rey, a laborer in Tumauini. Concepcion is working hard to help her husband in generating income for their needs. She ran various businesses since she got married.  At the moment, she is engaged in selling noodles and vegetables in in their village. The business somehow brings her happiness for she contributes income for her family. To further improve the business, Concepcion wanted to request a loan amounting to PHP4, 000 as additional business capital.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more used clothing

loans.name: Emar

texts.en:
Emar M. is from the village of Hinigdaan, Elsavador Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old, and is married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Emar owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Emar has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Emar joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emar is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
"Patience and diligence at work are the qualities we need to have to sustain our needs," says Lolita S.. Lolita is 54 years old and married to Eulogio, 57 years old, and a farmer. They live in Sitio Anguapan, Tumauini, Isabela, and are blessed with five children. Lolita is a loving mother and grandmother and all she wants is to have a successful way of living for her family.

Lolita has a livestock business raising poultry and pigs. She wanted a loan of 8,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to improve her business. Her livestock business is a big help in meeting the family's needs and Lolita hopes to sustain the business for the long term.

loans.use: To use as additional capital

loans.name: Rafiki Group

texts.en:
Saida is a member of the Rafiki borrower group In Msamvu,Morogoro,she is 42 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children.her children are aged 17,7,6 years.

Saida started her own business selling clothes 2 years ago.she works 6 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Saida`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzani,she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Saida hopes to save money and expand her business.

Farida,Sikujua,Turia are also the member of the same borrower group,they also requested the loan  in order to expand their business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline S. is from the village of Kauswagan. She is 42 years old, and is married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Evangeline joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her seventh from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian B. is from the village of Zone 1, Luyong Bonbon Opol, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old, and is a widow with three adult children. To make a living, Vivian owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling pork and chicken meat in the local community. Vivian has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Vivian joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vivian is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of her relatives and family members.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda has been able to send her only child to school through to college. However, her daughter wasn't able to graduate as she got married instead. Florenda earned the money to educate her daughter from her business producing and selling sweet delicacies. Now, since her dream of a better life for her child has not been realized, she wants to stabilize her business and make it grow in order to help her daughter. Florenda joined Kiva partner, ASHI, in the last week of July, and requested a loan for use as additional capital. 

Florenda also wants to start a charcoal business and a vegetable-selling business. One day, with the help of loans from ASHI, Florenda hopes to be able to produce a greater variety of sweet delicacies and sell them in different towns nearby. She would also like to purchase a motorcycle so that she can accept orders and deliver her products. Florenda also wants to build a canteen in one of the schools where she sells her products every day. Her ultimate dream of building a concrete house for her family will be in reach when she reaps the profits her businesses make.

loans.use: To finance her charcoal business, and sweet delicacy (food) business

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia T. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 49 years old. Lilia is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lilia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Brao

texts.en:
Brao L. is from the village of Luyong Bonbon, Opol Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old. Brao is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Brao owns and operates a specialized retail stall. She is into fish vending and "alacarte" business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Brao has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Brao joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brao is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Brao from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Brao O. is from the village of Zone 1, Luyong Bonbon, Opol Misamis Oriental. She is 60 years old. Brao is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Brao owns and operates a business venture as a fish vendor. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Brao has been engaged in her business for over 38 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Brao joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brao is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Brao from HSPFI. loans.name: Ramieh

texts.en:
Ramieh is a 46-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their three children. Ramieh has been selling clothes from her house. She also sells accessories, towels, lingerie, etc… She requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her work. This is the first time that Ramieh has requested a loan.

Ramieh is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and offers good quality merchandise. Her clients are her family members, friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. Ramieh decided on doing her business because she wanted to supplement her family's income. In the future, she plans on opening a shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her work.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a mother of six children. She is 30 years of age and is married to Alexis. Evelyn and Alexis's children range in age from two to 15 years old. Four of them go to school: the eldest and the second child are in high school.

Evelyn and her husband's source of income since last year is livestock raising. They had pig for hog fattening (pig raising), and ducks and chickens for a poultry-raising business. Evelyn realized that profit with these kinds of businesses is double as much as the capital thus she decided to join ASHI which opened a year ago in their town, to apply for a loan to be used in financing her poultry-raising.

Evelyn is so happy to have the opportunity of getting a loan because she really dreamed of strengthening her businesses and being able to get bigger profit. Profits she will be making out of the business financed by her loan will be used to send all of her children to school until college and for all of them to have better life in the future.

loans.use: To finance her duck- and chicken-raising business

loans.name: Urafiki Group

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Zuwena hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Anna,Jane,Zainabu are also the member of the same borrower group,they requested the loan in order to expand their business.

location.town: Upper Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Gibeon C1 Group

texts.en:
Gibeon C1 is a group of 8 farmers in Taloitan Village, Nekamese Subdistrict – Kupang District of East Nusa Tenggara Province. Taloitan is a small village which is situated about 37 km from Kupang City. Many coconut and banana trees grow in this village. Most people in this village have a background as farmers who lean on the agriculture sector in meeting their family needs. They usually sell their agricultural products at market in Kupang City as there is no local market available in this area. The challenge that the community faces in running their businesses is the meager availability of public transport in this area. The public transport only operates for 2 days in a week and it costs IDR 25,000 per return trip.

Gibeon C1 is led by Thomas B. - a 33-year-old man. Just as with many other people in this village, Thomas and his wife count on the agriculture sector for their livelihood. From their marriage, Thomas and his wife have been blessed with 3 children, they are: 
- Esthon B., 11 years old and in the Fifth Grade of Elementary School;
- Renita B., 9 years old and in the Fourth Grade of Elementary School; and 
- Rosana B., 6 years old and in the First Grade of Elementary School.
 
As the father of 3 children, Thomas always works hard to meet all of his family's daily needs by selling vegetables. Thomas and his wife are diligent in cultivating the farm and watering the vegetables on the farm every morning and evening. When the vegetables are ready to be harvested, they will bring them to Inpres Market to be sold on Tuesday and Thursday. They usually open the business in the market at 6 am and close around 2 pm. Nevertheless, the income that Thomas and his wife generate is still not enough to support their family. 

So Thomas and his neighbors decided to form a group of 8 farmers to join the cattle-fattening program. Thomas is interested in joining the program as he wants to improve his family's finances and to support his children’s education in the future. Thomas is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 3,400,000 from TLM to buy young cattle to fatten over 12 months. The other group members are also requesting a loan to buy young cattle. They really hope that the loan will help them in improving their living standards.  

Note: When the group picture was taken, Adrianus and Osias were replaced by family members.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed M. is 36 years old and a married father of five children. He lives in the Coastal Province of Kenya in a town called Miritini near Mombasa. M. runs a food kiosk in the same area and he has been in business for 15 years. His kiosk is situated in a densely populated area and hence he has been able to reach out to many customers.

This marks Mohamed's first loan from KADET and he plans to buy furniture, repair the walls of his hotel (in Kenya small cafes or restaurants are commonly called "hotels") and will buy food supplies.

Mohamed also acts as a cattle dealer and that has enabled him to supplement his food kiosk income. He hopes to open a butchery in future in the city of Mombasa.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To buy furniture, repair the walls of the 'hotel', and to buy food supplies

loans.name: Gibeon C2 Group

texts.en:
Yonatan J. is a 26-year-old man who lives with his parents in Taloitan Village, Nekamese Subdistrict, Kupang District. Yonatan leads a group of 8 farmers called Gibeon C2. Due to the low economic situation of his parents, Yonatan could only have primary education. After he graduated from the primary school, Yonatan began helping his parents, working as a farmer. He is still single and financially responsible for his family, including financing the education of his siblings; they are:
-	Frengky J., 14 years old, in the second grade of Elementary School; and
-	Janed J., 12 years old, in the first grade of Elementary School.
His parents and siblings rely on income that Yonatan generates from selling vegetables.  Yonatan is accustomed to work as a farmer because he has to meet his family's needs.  

Yonatan plants several types of vegetables such as “kangkung”, mustard greens, spinach, eggplants and celery. He sells the vegetables at Inpres Market which is situated about 37 km from the village. He spends the income from his business to meet his family's needs and his siblings’ school needs. Yonatan has difficulty planting the vegetables when the dry season comes as the water supply is limited in this season. 

Yonatan heard about the Cattle Fattening Program offered by TLM. He is interested in joining the program as he can generate profit from selling the fattened cattle. Together with other community members who were interested in joining the program, they formed Gibeon C2 Group. Yonatan is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 3,400,000 to buy young cattle to be fattened over a 12-month period. Yonatan hopes that this loan can help him in meeting his family's needs and his siblings’ educational needs. He wants his siblings to have a better future than he has. The other group members are also requesting the loan to buy young cattle to fatten. They also hope to have a better life through the loan.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Patwe Central Atimango Emilly Group

texts.en: A. Emilly is a group representative of Patwe Central, a hardworking business woman married with eight children of whom seven are schooling and she is a guardian of five children that are also at school. A. Emilly is using the loan to purchase cassava flour which she is purchasing in much volume for much more profit return. She has been in this business of selling cassava flour for eight years. The transport cost being high and the market being low, by the use of the loan this time she is managing to maintain her business well. Her future hope is to work hard, obtain some good money and continue paying school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase cassava flour which, she is purchasing in much volume for much more profit return.

loans.name: Elfe

texts.en:
Elfe B. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 36 years old. Elfe is separated and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Elfe owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Elfe has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Elfe joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elfe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elfe is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest another business such as selling beef and pork products known as "longganisa" in the local community. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Elfe from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Genelyn

texts.en:
Genelyn T. is from the village of Colupan Bajo,Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Genelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Genelyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Genelyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In March 2008, Genelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Genelyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Genelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
67-year-old Catalina's husband is a farmer while Catalina has her own hog-fattening (pig-raising) business, aside from helping her husband in the farm as a farmer as well. It has been five years now that Catalina and her husband have been able to have a rice-farming business. This has been a great source of income for the couple so they are able to send their only child to college until graduation.

Catalina's loan from ASHI when she joined in 2008 was used to finance this business instead of borrowing money from other people in their neighborhood which requires bigger interest rates per month. This was what they had been doing in the past when Catalina was not yet a member of ASHI and had no access to loans. Profit then was not really big and growing a business was very hard.

Now that Catalina has fully paid her first loan, she is requesting a much bigger loan to be able to accelerate the quality of rice they are producing for a better price and profit. Since Catalina is still using rice land which she doesn't own, every harvest they are required to give the owner of the land a share of the rice depending how many sacks they have agreed on for every acre. Someday, through her profit and helped by loans from ASHI, Catalina wished to purchase her own rice land.

loans.use: Will be used to finance her rice-farming business

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
G. Rano is 41 years old and comes from a large but humble family. She is married and the loving mother of two children. Her father's hard and demanding character showed her, from the time she was a little girl, the significant value of work, and therefore she has been successful in various activities throughout her life. Now Rano dedicates herself to raising and selling cattle, and with the income she generates, she provides a better quality of life for her children, who are her greatest joy and have become her best friends.

Rano is asking for a 4000 Somoni loan in order to buy more young cattle to later sell when they are fully grown. With this investment she will be able to substantially grow her earnings and improve her quality of life. Let’s support this dedicated mother's proposal.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing calves in order to expand the business

loans.name: Mumin

texts.en:
For the past 20 years, Mumin has worked in agriculture, raising animals. He raises cattle which he cares for greatly since thanks to them, he can cover his household expenses. Mumin showed us his animals with great happiness as his cattle were about to be vaccinated against the various sicknesses that affect that type of livestock. For Mumin, it is very important to work raising his animals which is why he is currently seeking a loan in order to purchase additional cattle so as to earn more money in future. That will help his family to generate additional income. We appreciate your support for Mumin’s projects.

loans.name: Emilienne

texts.fr: Emilienne est née le 20/12/1964 à Houeyogbé. Emilienne est mariée à Innocent, un technicien bâtiment. Emilienne et son mari ont un enfant et un autre qui n’est pas d’eux mais qui est à leur charge. Emilienne assure ensemble avec son mari les charges de la famille. Emilienne est dans le secteur de la restauration. C’est au pont bascule de Finagnon que Emilienne vend ses repas. Et Emilienne est dans cette activité depuis huit ans. Emilienne a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits de ALIDé. Emilienne a bien remboursé ces crédits et sollicite un quatrième crédit pour mieux développer son activité.
texts.en:
Emilienne was born on 20 December 1964 in Houeyogbé. Emilienne is married to Innocent, a building technician. Emilienne and her husband have one child of their own and another who is not theirs but is in their care. Together with her husband, Emilienne provides for her family. Emilienne works in the food service business. It is at the Finagnon weighbridge that Emilienne sells her meals. And Emilienne has been in this business for eight years. Emilienne has already received three previous loans through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). Emilienne repaid these loans without problems and is seeking a fourth loan to better develop her business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of rice, cans of food paste, and sauce condiments

loans.name: Akbar

texts.en:
Y. Akbar is a clothing merchant from Khujand, Tajikistan. He started his small business 7 years ago, and though much hard work, he has been able to develop it into quite a successful enterprise. His wife (pictured) is also engaged in this business.

Akbar has the qualities it takes to succeed as an entrepreneur. Goal-oriented, hard-working and punctual, he is a natural business man. Funding from IMON International has been instrumental in helping Akbar build his business. His first loan was for US$ 2500 and since that time he has benefited from one additional loan while establishing a great credit history. He has requested a loan of 1000 USD to add to his available working capital.

The ability to purchase large quantities of inventory in bulk saves time and expense for him. Akbar appreciates the availability of funding through IMON International. It allows him to take advantage of good opportunities and focus on growing his business so that he is able to adequately provide for himself and his family.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
C., 48 years old, is a married mother blessed with seven children; one is married and the others are single. Three of her single children are working at different occupations, and they have supported their own family’s living by providing some of their incomes.

C. currently works as massage staff in a hotel, while her husband is an electronic repairperson in the village. C. finds it hard traveling to work or anywhere else, because she doesn’t have her own vehicle since her personal money is not enough to buy one yet. Because of this, C. would like a loan of US$ 1000 in order to purchase a motorbike which she will use as transport.

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
66-year-old Estelita and her husband were left alone in their house after their children had their own family and lives away from their village. Aside from having an access to business capital through loan, Estelita joined ASHI in 2008 to be able to be with other women in their village and to make herself more friends. Loan she requested then was used as an additional capital to her variety store which was put up in 2007. Out of her profit from the store, she was able to buy piglet for her hog fattening (pig raising) business which profits twice as much as the capital after four months. Estelita has able to repaid her first loan. Now, she is applying for a much bigger loan intended for growing her variety store and buying another piglet for hog fattening business.
When Estelita's business would grow big the same as its profit, she would ask her children to come home and live with them and help her run their business because she wants her children living with her.

loans.use: Will be used to finance her variety store business and small portion of her loan will be used as an additional capital for her hog fattening (pig raising) business.

C’est Juliette et son mari qui assure ensemble les charges familiales. Juliette vend des céréales (maïs, riz, sorgho…). Juliette vend aussi du vin de palme localement produit. Juliette achète ses produits à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin ; et les vend chez elle à la maison. Juliette a déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits de la part de ALIDé pour ses activités ; crédits que Juliette a bien remboursés. Juliette sollicite un sixième crédit pour mieux développer ses activités.
texts.en:
Juliette was born around 1968 in Adja. Juliette is married to Innocent, a driver. Juliette and her husband have three children, all in school. It is Juliet and her husband who provide for their family together. Juliette sells cereals (maize, rice, sorghum, etc.). Juliette also sells locally-produced palm wine. Juliette buys her goods at Dantokpa, the grand international market in Benin, and sells them at home. Juliette has already received five loans through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) for her business; Juliette has repaid all of these loans properly. Juliette is seeking a sixth loan to better develop her business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and flasks of palm wine

loans.name: Y

texts.en: Y S. O. is 54-year-old a local farmer living in the rural area of Kampong Chhnang Province, in Cambodia. She has been farming since the early 1980 and is presently earning $2 a day. She is married years ago and has six children; three are married and have ready started new family homes. Two of her children are employed; one is a vender and other one is a tailor, while her husband is 56 years old, a military policeman. Recently, Y S. O. faces difficulty with plowing her own farmland due to the lack of farm supply. This obstacle, she has decided to request a loan of US$500 to add to her personal saving so she affords to buy a cultivating machine which she will use to plow her own farmland and other her neighbor’s farmland for fees.

loans.use: To buy a cultivating machine

loans.name: Mary Grace M

texts.en:
Mary Grace M L. is from the village of Katipunan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is twenty-nine years old and married with one school-aged child. To make a living, Mary Grace owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Mary Grace has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $42 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Mary Grace joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to  purchase fertilizers such as manure. Mary Grace is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be her third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative: PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida D. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 50 years old. Zenaida is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling rice products in the local community. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Zenaida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Zenaida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Donah

texts.en:
Donah is twenty-six years old and married with two children between the ages of one and four. One of her children goes to school. Donah also takes care of additional family members. She resides and works in a semi-urban area where she rents a four-room house which has no electricity and no piped water, but the family does get three meals a day.

She doesn’t incur any extra transportation costs for buying her merchandise, because she buys from suppliers who get charcoal from surrounding villages. Donah works seven days a week and sells to an average of twenty customers a day, from all categories of people. She has been in this business for five years. Her major monthly expenses include rent for her business and residence plus medication.

Donah has been with MCDT for two years servicing her fourth loan, and working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She has hopes of seeing her business grow bigger and eventually owning a permanent business location and home.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Bashorat

texts.en:
Bashorat B. is forty-three years old and married with two children. She has been running her own small business for three years. She rents a store in the local market where she sells daily foodstuffs. She works from 8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. She is very friendly and polite, which attracts customers. She is requesting $800 to increase the range of the goods she sells. She needs to be able to provide for her children's needs and to pay their school fees. She promises to repay her loan without any delay and thanks everybody who decides to support her.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy a wider range of goods and to increase her stock

loans.name: Patwe Koi Oyaba Rose Group

texts.en: Oyaba R. is a treasurer of her group that is Patwe Koi. She is forty-three years old, widowed with nine children where by only two are at school. She deals with fish business where she has been selling for over twenty years. She is using the loan to purchase fish from the source for sale which is greatly enabling her business run well. She is an active business woman although single handed, she is struggling to finance her business as well managing to see that she survives all together with her family. Oyaba R. is so encouraging and her dream is to educate her children and obtain live stock for future support

loans.use: To purchase fish from the source for sale which is greatly enabling her business run well.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 28 year married with three children aged between 3 and 12 years. All her children go to school She resides and rents a two roomed house where she is staying with five people. Grace doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is electricity and no piped water at her home.  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area.   She doesn’t incur any extra transport as she buys from her place of work running a restaurant   She sells to 30 customers a day. Grace sells to all categories of people and works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include rent for business and residence plus medication. She has been in this business for the last two years Grace has been with MCDT for four years servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more cooking oil and store other food stuffs like beans ground nuts rice maize flour. Grace and is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger. owning a fully accomplished hotel 
 

.

loans.use: To  stock more  cooking oil  ground nuts maize four nad bananas

loans.name: Sadriddin

texts.en:
E. Sadriddin has always been a hard-working man, who has made sure from a young age that his family never went hungry. He is married with two children. Six years ago, and with a starting capital of only $100, Sadriddin started a grocery store for selling different kinds of foodstuffs. Thanks to his perseverance and dedication, his business has expanded and now his whole family is involved.

Today Sadriddin needs to increase the range of goods he sells. For this purpose he is requesting a loan of $900. He is ready to work even harder and to make sacrifices to achieve his goal of becoming a successful entrepreneur. loans.use: To increase the range of goods to sell

loans.name: Félicienne

texts.fr: Félicienne est née vers 1975 à Abomey au Centre du Bénin. Félicienne est mariée à Eustache. Félicienne a fait le cours primaire. Félicienne et son mari ont quatre enfants tous scolarisés. Félicienne supporte ensemble avec son mari les dépenses de la famille. C’est des condiments de sauces que Félicienne vend au carrefour Dégakon. Félicienne s’approvisionne en ces produits à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Félicienne a déjà quatre ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Félicienne a déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits de la part de ALIDé pour ses activités ; crédits que Félicienne a bien remboursés. Félicienne sollicite un cinquième crédit pour constituer de grands stocks de ses produits.
texts.en:
Félicienne was born around 1975 in Abomey, in the centre of Benin. Félicienne is married to Eustache. Félicienne has a first grade education. Félicienne and her husband have four children, all in school. Félicienne supports her family and their expenses together with her husband. Félicienne sells condiments at the Dégakon crossroads. Félicienne supplies herself with these products at Dantokpa, the grand international market in Benin. Félicienne has already gained four years of experience in this business. Félicienne has already received four loans through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) for her business; she repaid all of these loans properly. Félicienne is seeking a fifth loan to generate large stockpiles of her goods.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of onions, garlic, packets of pepper, baskets of fresh tomatoes, baskets of hot peppers, etc.

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato T. is thirty-seven years old and married with two children. They are John Angelo, who is sixteen years old and a college freshman and John Emmanuel, who is eight years old and in the third grade. Renato, his wife Rowena, and their children live in Baranay Canciller along the City Proper of Cauayan. He describes his family as being God-fearing. 

Renato previously worked as a manager at ACT machineries located in Cauayan City. He resigned when he felt called to the ministry in his church. He also decided to put up his "John 3:16" shop, selling musical instruments. He also sells Christian accessories, books, book marks, souvenirs and a lot more in order to provide for his family's daily needs and his children's education. Aside from managing the business, Renato also offers music tutorials because he is also a good musician.

His desire to further improve his business and to share his musical skills with others, along with his willingness to disseminate God’s love, causes Renato to seek the support of Kiva lenders. He is asking for a loan of PHP50,000 for the expansion of his business. He already has one branch in Aurora and has ten employees. He hopes that in the coming days, he will be able to expand the business even more.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Yusufu Hawa’S Group

texts.en:
Y. is forty years old and single with three children between the ages of seventeen and twenty-two years. She rents a one-room house where she lives with five people. Y. doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is no electricity and no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area where she sells charcoal. She doesn’t incur any extra transportation costs because she buys from her place of work.

Y. sells charcoal in the Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, and on average she receives thirty customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. She has been in this business for the last five years. Y. has been with MCDT for five years servicing her eighth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. Y. hopes to see her business grow bigger and wants to eventually own a permanent business location and home.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Farhod

texts.en:
M. Farhod is married and has a young son. With the faith that his son could go to school, he started a business of processing and selling dried apricots to be able to make enough money to pay for his schooling. This is why he started this business five years ago. He is experienced in this kind of business that allows him to expand his clientele day by day. Right now Farhod needs a loan of 3000 Somoni. He is going to spend the loan to purchase more dried apricots, which he will process further and sell. With your help, Farhod will be able to feel proud that through much effort, his son went to school and is an honorable person.

loans.use: To buy dried apricots for expanding his business

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya A. is already 44 years old, she manages a livestock raising business for already 2 years. She is able to earn an income of PHP2, 000 in every four months for one pig alone if it’s fully grown. She plans to avail a loan to able develop further her pig raising business into a bigger one. She knows that having her loan request of PHP7, 000 will surely be of big part in the pursuit of her business endeavor. Ligaya on the other hand is patiently making the business good and desirable no matter how bad its odor to others. 

Ligaya is married to Dante A. who is a house carpenter in their village of Barangay Pulay Luna, Isabela. They were blessed with 3 children namely Jeffrey - 18 years old, he is now second year in college, followed by Jake - 17 years old is a high school undergrad and Junell - 11 years old is currently in the primary school. The family helps each other in achieving their family goals in life.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is 30 years of age. She is married to Gilbert B. who is a simple farmer. They have two children: Jay Lord who is 10 years of age and Jayson who is 4 years old. Her eldest child is already attending primary school while her youngest will soon enter pre-school. Her family lives in the simple village of Barangay Pulay of Luna, Isabela. 
 
She has managed a livestock business for almost a year and because of a lack of financial capital, she is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders in the amount of PHP5,000 to be able to maintain the business. As a beginner in managing a business, Virginia believes that having enough capital will be a great factor in somehow becoming successful in the business. She also believes that “great things begin from humble beginnings” and now her main principle in life is to become successful in the future from her chosen business of hog raising.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is 25 years old and single. He owns a grocery store in Hebron city , Palestine. He would like to increase trade by purchasing canned goods, soft drinks and other products for his shop. Doing so means he would be able to contribute to improving the standard of living for his family.

loans.use: Increase trade by purchasing canned goods, soft driks and other products for his shop.

loans.name: Antiponan

texts.en:
Antiponan R. is from the village of Jasaan , Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old. Antiponan is married and has 11 school-aged children. To make a living, Antiponan owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of flowers in the local community. Antiponan has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from her activities.

In 2009, Antiponan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Antiponan is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Antiponan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 55 years old and divorced with four children aged between 22 and 36 years of age. None of her children go to school. She resides and rents a one room house where she stays with five people. Mariam takes care of additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water into her home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area. She buys charcoal from delivery trucks which get the charcoal from villages. She doesn’t incur any extra transport costs as she buys from her place of work. She sells to 20 customers a day. Mariam sells to all categories of people and works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include rent for business and residence plus medication. She has been in this business for the last two years.

Mariam has been with MCDT, a Kiva partner, for six years servicing her twelfth loan and working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal as it is getting towards the rainy season and during the rainy season rural roads becomes impassable. Mariam aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business location as well as a home. .

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Zulola

texts.en:
O. Zulola is 20-years old. She is not married and lives with her parents. Zulola is a market vendor who sells fabrics for national dresses in the local market. Zulola started this business because she needed money to be able to support her parents and to pay for household and personal expenses. Zulola has been in this business for 2 years. For these years she managed to make her business stable and profitable so that she can generate the income she needs for her family. Now Zulola is planning to expand her business and is requesting a loan of $800. This will enable her to have a wide assortment of fabrics. She promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all those supporting her.

loans.use: To purchase fabric to sell for making national dresses

loans.name: Suraiyokhon

texts.en:
For the last four years Suraiyokhon has been selling basic grains in the city of Isfara. She is a woman worthy of being imitated. After not being able to cover her home expenses by being a housewife, she used her savings of about USD $100, which she had for emergencies, and started her business. IMON International has supported Suraiyokhon by facilitating loans to her for the last three years. In spite of the strong competition in her type of business, her results have been improving and therefore it has been proposed to continue granting her credit. Currently Suraiyokhon needs a loan of $1000 USD to increase the range of her goods for sale. She and her family appreciate your support in helping her improve her business.

loans.use: Increasing stock and purchasing additional goods to sell

loans.name: On

texts.en:
On C., 27 years old, is married to Mr. So Sann, age 29, and they live with their two children in their medium-sized family home in Siem Reap Province. This couple earns a living by buying and selling used goods in the village and typically makes their current income of US$ 6 per day to help alleviate the destitution of their family’s living conditions.

The family own and always use their old bicycle to support their business. On C. will be using her loan to purchase a used motorcycle to be used instead of her old bicycle. With the motorcycle as transportation, she will be able to be faster.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 42-year-old widow with five children, aged between 13 and 18. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she is living with eight people. Margaret takes care of two additional family members. There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Margaret resides and works in a semi-urban area where she deals in cold drinks and refreshments. She incurs extra transport costs from and to shopping for her goods. Margaret owns a small restaurant with on average of 30 customers a day,and she sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week.

Margaret's major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. She has been in this business for the last five years. Margaret has been with MCDT for five years and is servicing her eighth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bananas and rice. Margaret is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning rental rooms. .

loans.use: To buy more bananas and rice

loans.name: Burkhon

texts.en:
Y. Burkhon lives in Isfara, Tajikistan. He is 51 years old, married and has three children. Burkhon is the sole provider for his family and earns his living by raising and selling cows and sheep at the local market. Thanks to his effort some years ago Burkhon was able to arrange the wedding of his son. Once in 2-3 months he purchases young animals from local villagers and raises them over an 8-9 month period and later sells the adult cows and sheep to local butchers. Today Burkhon is thinking about expanding his business, as his current earnings are not enough to provide for his family. He plans to purchase young cattle. That’s why he is requesting a loan of $650 USD. Extend your solidarity to Burkhon so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.
