loans.use: To purchase spare parts in order to repair his minivan

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina, 39, is married and mother of four children, all in school. Working very hard to support the husband in taking care of the family, Faustina trades in cooking oil and slippers. Operating these two businesses in seasons has helped her to know the market trend and what to invest her money in. Her only challenge is in having adequate funds to operate successfully, so she is requesting a loan to purchase an increased stock of cooking oil since this is the season of high demand. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of cooking oil and slippers.

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda D., from the village of Manticao, Iligan City, is a 42-year-old married mother of three school-aged children. To make a living, Rhoda makes and sells specialty food products in the local community. Rhoda has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rhoda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to expand the business, she is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her second loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Zarbibi

texts.ru: Зарбиби Махмудова проживает в районе Регар. Возраст 55 лет. Замужем, имеет 8 детей. Зарбиби более 5 лет занимается торговлей. Она имеет торговую точку на рынке, где торгует клиенкой. Муж также занимается предоставлением услуги такси. Кредит просит для закупа нового ассортимента.
texts.en:
Zarbibi M., 55, lives in Regar district. She is married with eight children. For over five years, Zarbibi has ben selling at the market and has a trading stall there where she sells plastic covers. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Zarbibi is applying for a loan to purchase additional goods to sell.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: This woman, who is employed as a commune officer in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, is requesting a loan of $400 to renovate parts of her house and invest in her general store, where she sells food ingredients, plastics, and some other kitchen accessories, assisted by her nephew.

loans.use: To invest in her store, and renovate parts of her house

loans.name: Juanito

texts.en:
Juanito S., 49 years old and single, is from the village of Casusan. To make a living, he owns and operates a "sari-sari" store, selling a variety of products in the local community. Juanito has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Juanito joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan from PMPC, he is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be his seventh from PMPC, and he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn T. is from the village of Dullan. She is 49 years old. Arlyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Arlyn operates a fruit-vending business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling fruits and vegetables for sale. Arlyn has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2004, Arlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Arlyn is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 15th loan taken out by Arlyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley is a 45-year-old father of three who lives and operates his electronics shop in the Mukuru slums of Nairobi. He began his business nine years ago after working in a bar for 12 years. Stanley has applied for a second loan of Ksh. 60,000 after successfully repaying a first loan of Ksh. 30,000. He wants to use the loan to add stock of cables and electrical fittings. He hopes to one day have many branches outside Nairobi and educate his children to the highest level. Stanley describes himself as ambitious, social, friendly and hardworking.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable micro-finance institution that offers savings and credit services to more than 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Anvarjon

texts.en:
The business activity from which N. Anvarjon makes a living is the breeding of livestock. He started this business 10 years ago with a small number of livestock, but as his business has developed, he has acquired greater quantities of animals for their eventual sale and gain from their derivatives. According to Anvarjon, he works very hard so that he can maintain his children. For that reason, he is always looking for a way to improve the living of his family. Currently Anvarjon needs a loan of 5000 Somoni in order to purchase more cattle and later resell after breeding them. This will allow him to fully meet the need of his family and educate all of his children.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle for developing business

loans.name: Vikie

texts.en:
Vikie D. is from the town of Aloran. She is 35 years old. Vikie is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Vikie operates a retail rice business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling rice in the local community. Vikie has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vikie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vikie is requesting a new loan of 2,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Vikie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

Gina D. is from the village of Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old. Gina is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 43 years old and is married with four children. Three children are currently in school, while her first-born is learning a trade. Esther has been selling plastic materials like plates, buckets, bowls, cooking utensils, etc. for ten years. For the cooking utensils, she sells through hawking -- door to door selling. She has a lot of marketing experience, and it has helped her in her business growth. Demand for her goods is booming and she sells during the market days. She requests a loan to augment her working capital in order to buy more stock of cooking utensils and plastic materials to sell. She believes the loan will enable her to raise more income to support her family.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell
